page.title: 02Tadcaster Local History
page.content: Tadcaster is steeped in{local history. The{Romans}named the town Calcaria, which is a reference to the hard limestone on which the town stands. Tadcaster was used by the Romans as a staging post on the way to York. They built a castle on what is now called Castle Hill. The arrival of the {railways}in the 1840s took much of the coaching traffic away from the town but the{breweries}began to develop. The viaduct was built in 1849 by George Hudson to carry the York line over the River Wharfe, but the line was never completed and the viaduct is used as a footpath. The first stone church was built about 1150 AD. The church flooded a lot and so it was rebuilt five feet higher and reopened in 1877.
